original_title: Spike in Cases Prompts Island-Wide Dengue Control Program
original_body_lines: COLOMBO (News 1st); In response to a recent surge in dengue fever cases, the National Dengue Control Unit (NDCU) announced a five-day intensive mosquito control program across six provinces.
The program, targets the Western, Southern, Sabaragamuwa, Central, Northern, and Eastern provinces.
"With the onset of the inter-monsoon season, we've observed a significant rise in dengue cases," stated Dr. Nalin Ariyaratne, Director of the NDUC.
Prior to the program's rollout, a two-day entomology survey will be conducted across the targeted provinces to assess mosquito breeding sites and species distribution.
This data will inform the targeted deployment of control measures such as larviciding, fogging, and community outreach initiatives.
As of today, Sri Lanka has recorded a concerning 82,036 dengue cases and 49 deaths in 2023.
Recognizing the urgency of the situation, the NDUC emphasizes the importance of both individual and community-level preventive measures.

Dengue fever, transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, is characterized by symptoms like high fever, severe headache, muscle and joint pain, nausea, and vomiting. If you experience any of these symptoms, seek immediate medical attention.
Mosquito bite prevention: Apply insect repellent containing. Wear long sleeves and pants, especially during peak mosquito hours (dawn and dusk).
Mosquito habitat elimination: Eliminate stagnant water sources around homes, breeding grounds for mosquitoes.
Community clean-up drives: Regularly remove potential breeding sites like discarded tires and containers.
